Just had a few more thoughts on this one. Consider a family tree of
genomes=
 where each mutation is a essentially a choice to go down one
branch of the=
 tree. For a genome at the end of a branch to evolve into
a genome at the e=
nd of another branch evolution would probably have to
back-track up the tre=
e and back down again. Because successive genomes
are building on previous =
generations it's unlikely a more direct
evolutionary path between the two g=
enoems exists.

If we compare this situation to moving around in a euclidea=
n space
then I'm saying that the direct path from A to B isn't available, t=
hat
we have to traverse first on the X axis and then the Y axis (or vice
ve=
rsa), thus the simple distance calculation we have been using is
probably m=
ore correct in giving us an evolutionary distance between
two genomes. 

It=
 would be nice to see some experimental results backing up this
hypothesis =
- it would be straightforward to tweak the compatibility
calculation and co=
mpare results.

Colin.
